metadata.title: Development and Characterization of Nano-emulsions Based on Oil Extracted from Black Soldier Fly Larvae

sections.text:
Keywords Black soldier fly. Insect oil . TPGS .Hydrogenated lecithin .Nano-emulsions, insectbased biorefinery
The presenting author of this manuscript in ACB2019 is Daniel Setiyo Nugroho.
* Tzung-Han Chou chouth@yuntech.edu.tw
Extended author information available on the last page of the article

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of the global population and economy, a huge amount of agricultural and food waste is being generated worldwide and becoming a recognized public issue. These organic wastes can cause several environmental and public health problems if not handled properly [1]. Bioconversion of agricultural and food wastes to value-added products, such as fuels, materials, and chemicals, has attracted a lot of attention and many interests in the field of sustainable development.
Insect-based biorefinery has been seen as a promising approach to recycling agricultural and food wastes for value-added products in the last decades. Currently, many different species of insect had been invested for their applicability as an agent to convert agricultural and food wastes [2–5]. Black soldier fly (Hermetia illucens) larvae (BSFL) is one of the most promising candidates because of its favorable characteristics such as easy cultivation, fast-growing, and worldwide distribution [6, 7]. BSFL has great potential to consume various organic waste in a large amount during its life span. A range of organic wastes including animal manure, manure [1], agricultural residues [8–10], and food processing wastes [11] was successfully converted by black soldier fly into larval biomass. Furthermore, BSFL generates half of the residue amount of compost as compared to fresh biowaste composting process, thus, releasing lower emission to the environment [7], and potential to replace conventional feed protein sources to lower the environmental impact of food production [6]. Moreover, BSFL has antimicrobial activity against the growth of gram-negative bacteria, gram-positive bacteria, and filamentous fungi which will evoke a safe application for human consumptions [12].
One problem that could limit the development of insect-based biorefinery is the low market price of the insect biomass [13]. One of the solutions is to increase the value of products derived from insect biomass. Value-added applications or products could promote the growth of interest in the industry of using insects as bio-converter. Several products could be separated and purified from the insect biomass including proteins, lipids, chitin, and pigments. The meal derived from insect biomass was proven to be a potential protein and several essential ingredient sources to substitute fish and soybean [14–16]. The insect oil had also been investigated in many studies for the production of biofuels [17, 18]. Currently, there was no report discussed the behavior and application of lipid from BSFL as a carrier of drug or bioactive in the form of oil-in-water (O/W) nano-emulsions.
Nano-emulsions are formulated by adding emulsifiers into the mixture of oil and water with the aids of physical homogenization. The emulsifiers are adsorbed onto the oil-water interface to reduce the interfacial tension and form dispersed droplets [19]. Nevertheless, nano-emulsions are thermodynamically unstable systems that require the emulsifiers to sustain their stability during preparation and storage. Avariety of emulsifiers can be used to stabilize nano-emulsions, such as anionic, nonionic, cationic, double tail, or Gemini structure emulsifier [20, 21]. In some cases, the formation, stability, and functional properties of nano-emulsions can be further improved by using combinations of different emulsifiers [19, 22, 23]. For example, Riquelme et al. found that the emulsifier mixture of 5% lecithin and 1% tween 80/quillaja saponin can enhance the thermal stability of avocado oil-based nano-emulsions, which could be useful for processing emulsion-based food products [24]. Another study published by Cheong et al. also showed that the kenaf seed oil-in-water nano-emulsions can be stabilized using ternary emulsifier mixtures [25]. Nevertheless, there is currently a relatively poor understanding of the impact of mixed emulsifier systems on nano-emulsions formation and properties.
To promote the value of BSFL oil based on the biorefinery concept, this study aimed to develop a novel nano-emulsion with BSFL oil as a lipophilic compound combining nonionic TPGS and amphoteric HL as the emulsifiers. TPGS and HL can be functionalized as an excellent solubilizer, emollient, permeation, emulsifier, and bioavailability enhancer to form mixed nano-emulsions systems that intended to improve their physicochemical characteristics [26, 27]. Since physicochemical characteristics of colloids play a key role in the development of drug delivery systems [28, 29], transmission electron microscopy, dynamic light scattering, differential scanning calorimetry, and fluorescence polarization were utilized to investigate properties of BSFL oil nanoemulsions. Furthermore, the effect of the nano-emulsions constituents on their physical properties and storage stability was also evaluated. The results derived from this work would provide useful information for designing BSFL oil-based nano-emulsions that suitable for a wide range of applications such as drug, nutrient, cosmetic delivery systems.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text: The dried black soldier fly larvae (BSFL) at fifth instar was provided by Wormax Inc. (Yunlin, Taiwan) then further identified the fatty acids content shown in Table 1. Hexane and phosphoric acid were purchased from J.T. Baker, USA. Sodium hydroxide and 1,6- diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatriene (DPH) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA. Activated carbon and acidic clay were gained from Gau Jiuh International. CO., LTD. D-αTocopheryl polyethylene glycol 1000 succinate (TPGS) was purchased from BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany). Hydrogenated lecithin (HL) was supplied from Nisshin OilliO (Tokyo, Japan). Uranyl acetate was obtained from Alfa Aesar company (USA). Double distilled water produced from a Milli-Q plus purification system (Millipore, USA) was used for all preparations of nano-emulsions.

sections.heading: BSFL Oil Preparation
sections.text:
The dried BSFL was processed using a food homogenizer (TM-787, TWK Co., Ltd., Taiwan) to obtain the larval paste. The larval paste was then extracted with 10 times the volume of hexane at 60 °C in an enclosed glass vessel and stirred at 150 rpm for 1 h followed by settling for 30 min. The hexane layer was separated from the water layer followed by filtrating through a glass microfiber filter (Grade GF/D, Whatman®). The extraction process was repeated twice to obtain the oil. The collected hexane layer containing BSFL oil was then fed into a rotary vacuum evaporator at 45 °C and 20 mmHg to separate the hexane from the crude oil.
The crude BSFL oil was purified sequentially by degumming, dewaxing, and bleaching. Briefly, for degumming and dewaxing, 100 g of BSFL crude oil was heated to 70 °C followed by adding 0.2 ml 99% H3PO4 (w/v) and stirred for 30 min. Then, 10 g of 15% NaOH (w/v) was added into the crude oil and reacted for 30 min to neutralize the oil. After neutralization, the crude oil was centrifuged at 6000×g for 5 min. The bleaching process was performed by adding 0.5 g of activated carbon and 1.5 g of acidic clay to the degummed and dewaxed oil. The sample was then stirring at 150 rpm for 30 min followed by filtration through a qualitative filter paper (Grade No. 1, Whatman®). The filtrate was used as the purified BSFL oil for the following experiments. The oil content was determined and listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: Preparation of BSFL Oil Nano-emulsions
sections.text: Nano-emulsions are prepared by the oil phase, 1% and 2% BSFL oil and the total emulsifier consisted of surfactant ratio (SR) of HL/TPGS at 0/100, 25/75, 50/50, 75, 25, 100/0 with surfactant to oil ratio (SOR) of 30%, 50%, and 60% in the aqueous phase. For preparing nanoemulsions, the oil phase and aqueous phase were pre-heating in 80 °C in 4 min then homogenized with D-500 homogenizer (Wiggen Hausser, Germany) at 15,000 rpm for 2 min. Then, the dispersion sample was sonicated with an ultra-sonicator (Misonix 3000, USA) under a power of 60 W at 45 °C for 20 min. After ultrasonication, a 4-mL sample was obtained and each formulation repeated three times (n = 3) at least.

sections.heading: Characteristic Observation by TEM
sections.text: The morphology of the nano-emulsions was visualized with transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TEM samples were observed under the operation of a transmission electron microscope (HITACHI H-7500, Japan) at 100 kV. For TEM analyze, approximately 5 μL of nano-emulsions was dropped onto a 3-mm carbon film coated copper grid. After removing an excess sample, the uranyl acetate (1% w/v) solution was added and left for drying at room temperature for 24 h. The bright film-imaging mode was used to obtain TEM images.

sections.heading: Droplet Size, PDI, and Zeta Potential Measurement
sections.text:
Dynamic light scattering (DLS) experiments for nano-emulsions were carried out by using a Zeta Plus Analyzer (Brookhaven Instruments Corporation, USA). Measurement was done with dilution for 20 times of nano-emulsions solution in pure water at room temperature. Hydrodynamic particle size and polydispersity index were obtained from
the automatic cycle calculation in 3 min. The zeta potential distribution of nanoemulsions was determined with the same instrument by measuring the electrophoretic mobility and then determined by using the Smoluchowski equation. All the sample was repeated triplicate (n = 3) at least.

sections.heading: Rheology Study
sections.text: Rheological experiments for samples were performed by a DV-Ш Ultra programmable rheometer (Brookfield, USA) with CP40 spindle using cone and plate geometry. Nanoemulsions solution was pipetted with a volume of 0.5 mL and placed in the center of the chamber. The rheological analysis consisted of three steps: A cooling ramp from room temperature to 25 °C for 3 min, yield stress determination at 25 °C by a stress sweep from 0.1 Pa to 500 Pa with a frequency of 0.1 Hz, then auto-calculation using Herschel-Bulkley model. All measurements were performed with triplicate.

sections.heading: Thermal Analysis of Nano-emulsions by DSC
sections.text: The differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), DSC 1 instrument with the STARe system (Mettler Toledo Inc., Switzerland) was used to exploit the phase transitions of nanoemulsions. Twenty-microliter samples were placed in aluminum pans and then sealed, while 20-μL water-sealed pans were used as a reference. The sealed pans were placed in the DSC chamber with an initial temperature of 25 °C. For all DSC measurements, samples were heated and cooled at a scan rate of 5 °C/min with three circles in the temperature range of − 10~80 °C.

sections.heading: Fluorescence Polarization Measurement
sections.text:
The 1,6-diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatriene (DPH) was used as a fluorescence polarization probe for measuring intra-nano-emulsion molecular fluidity. Appropriate amount of DPH was incorporated in the oil phase for each sample and analyzed using a fluorescence spectrometer (Perkin Elmer LS 55, USA). The measurement of vertical and horizontal polarization was done in the excitation wavelength of 360 nm (Ivv) and the emission wavelength at 450 nm (Ivh). The degree of polarization was obtained by the following equation from the average of 10 measurement cycles at 25 °C, where G = 1 is the built-in factor of the instrument [30]. All samples were repeated triplicate (n = 3).
P ¼ Ivv−G⋅Ivh Ivv þ G⋅Ivh ð1Þ

sections.heading: Stability Analysis of Nano-emulsions
sections.text: To investigate the dispersion stability, all samples were kept in room temperature with low light intensity. Visual observation and DLS measurements were done every day for the first week, then followed every 7 days. The unstable nano-emulsion solution was judged by average particle size ≥ 800 nm, polydispersity index ≥ 0.6, and/or the bulk phase separation phenomenon such as flocculation and precipitates at the bottom of the bottle.

sections.heading: Statistical Analysis
sections.text: All the experiments were repeated three times. Error bars represent the standard deviations. The p < 0.0001 was calculated with one-way ANOVA using Design Expert 10 software. Numerical optimization carried out to get the optimum point for average particle size.

sections.heading: Morphology Assay
sections.text: TEM is a very powerful tool and has been widely used for observation of the morphological characteristics of nano-scale colloids. Figure 1 shows the TEM images for freshly prepared nano-emulsions with various surfactant ratios of HL/TPGS as SOR = 60% and oil content = 1%. One can see that the existence of nearly spherical particles and the size distribution is different for each formulation. This indicates that BSFL oil adding with HL and TPGS can form nano-scale colloids in water. Besides, the size of nano-colloids for pure HL is larger than that of those for TPGS and HL/TPGS = 75/25, suggesting that the incorporation of TPGS into HL nano-emulsions would induce the molecular rearrangement. A similar decrease effect of TPGS on the size of Tween 80 nano-emulsions was also found [31], whereas inversely results were reported for poly(lactide)/TPGS nanoparticle systems [32]. Generally, the bulky of PEG(2000) group can impart sufficient curvature of particles [33], but neighbor constituent interaction shall not be neglected in the nano-colloids. As will be confirmed in the following section, the sizes of BSFL oil nano-emulsions visualized by TEM were virtually agreed with those determined by DLS.

sections.heading: DLS Characterization of BSFL Oil Nano-emulsions
sections.text:
Figure 2 illustrates the average particle size, polydispersity index, and zeta potential of BSFL oil nano-emulsions with various surfactant ratios of HL/TPGS at different SOR and oil content obtained from DLS measurement. The APS of BSFL oil nano-emulsions was found to be significantly affected by the SOR and surfactant ratio (p < 0.0001) rather
than oil content (p = 0.1921), where increasing SOR and surfactant ratio causes a decrease in the size of nano-emulsions. This result may be explained by the fact that an abundant amount of surfactant will provide a stronger reduced ability in surface tension and higher contact probability to interact with oil rather than low SOR. Such an effect may tighten molecular distance, resulting in a decrease in particle size. In the case of oil content, a higher amount of oil in nano-emulsions does not cost any noticeable change in particle size. This indicates that the nano-emulsion size is more significantly affected by the partition equilibrium of surfactant in solution by compared with oil content.
As for the surfactant ratio effect, the presence of TPGS significantly maintained the particle in small size even in the lowest TPGS concentration at the surfactant ratio of HL/TPGS = 75/ 25. The appearance of TPGS can give the bulky PEG head group in the HL nano-emulsion surface, inducing high curvature of particles [33, 34]. Furthermore, the concept of molecular packing parameter is widely invoked in the literature to rationalize and even predict selfassembly structure in surfactant solutions [35]. Herein, TPGS known has a conical structure with packing parameter ¼–½, which causes the arrangement of molecule tighter and curvier. HL is known as a rectangle structure with packing parameters ½–1/3, which causes the arrangement of the molecule to become weaker and less curvy [35]. This confirmed that the TPGS can provide a downsizing effect on HL nano-emulsions. It is interesting to note in Fig. 2b that the polydispersity index of nano-emulsions with mixed binary surfactants is larger than that of single HL or TPGS nano-emulsions. This phenomenon may be related to the miscibility between TPGS and HL. Besides, the results of zeta potential (Fig. 2d) display that an increase of HL amount in the nano-emulsions induces a decrease in the zeta potential. This may be due to HL used in this work is negatively charged [36].

sections.heading: Rheology Behavior of BSFL Oil Nano-emulsions
sections.text: Viscosity measurement of BSFL oil nano-emulsions solution was performed to understand the flow behavior. Figure 2c shows that the flow index of BSFL oil nano-emulsions with various surfactant ratios of HL/TPGS at different SOR and oil content. As the surfactant ratio of HL/ TPGS ≤ 50/50, the flow index value was close to 1, suggesting that the flow behavior of these formulations was nearly Newtonian liquid. Further increasing HL amount over 50%, the flow index of samples < 1 was found. This implies that the presence of a rich-HL amount in the nano-emulsions may changes the flow behavior of the dispersion become shear thinning. Such a result may be associated with the modification of nanostructure of dispersion by HL amount reported elsewhere [37].

sections.heading: Stability Study and Visual Observation
sections.text:
The stability of nano-emulsions is one of the crucial aspects that should not be neglected for all consumer goods since it is improbable for direct uses after production and necessary need for long term storage. Using visual observation, the appearance of the NE is different for each composition. Figure 3a shows that the most transparent solution was in the surfactant ratio of 75/25, which gives very high storage stability until 365 days. Emulsion with high transparency has a low refractive index which related to the small particle involve inside the solution. Therefore, the transparency of the nano-emulsion has the same tendencies with the particle size trend. These phenomena are in the same agreement with another report [38] where combining of water-soluble surfactant and a water-insoluble phospholipid can result in a single surfactant micelle, mixed micelle, or mixed dispersions. Furthermore, it was found that a micellar or mixed micellar formation will generate an isotropically clear solution [39].
While HL was used alone as a surfactant in the BSFL oil nano-emulsions, a white cream layer was observed on the surface of the solution after reach 2–7 days (Fig. 3b). Although the HL nano-emulsions have the lowest zeta potential value, the huge size of particles was found and phase separation appeared. In most cases, the destabilization of nano-emulsions dispersion is caused by the phase transition, gravitational force, and flocculation or Ostwald ripening [40]. Creaming is one of the frequently observed phenomena in this system because of the oil phase density is lower than the aqueous phase density. Moreover, HL known has low solubility in water which more likely acts as a hydrophobic surfactant. So that the oiling-off does not happen, which means that the oil phase does not separate from the surfactant. It is proved that HL has an excellent performance to incorporate the oil phase in their environment.

sections.heading: Endothermic Phase Behavior
sections.text:
The differential scanning calorimetry was conducted as a thermal analysis to investigate not only the endothermic phase behavior of the nano-emulsions but also another related interaction of surfactant, oil, and the environment. The resulting thermograms of BSFL oil nanoemulsions varied with different surfactant ratios of HL/TPGS at various oil content and SOR is shown in Fig. 4. Two phase transition regions were found in the temperature range of − 4 to 37 °C (phase transition region 1, P1) and 56–68 °C (phase transition region 2, P2). Moreover, there are several fused transitions, combining become one broad phase transition that was indicating the membrane phase separation. At fixed oil content and SOR, one can find that the endothermic curve of HL nano-emulsions exhibits the larger size of P2 without obvious alteration in size of P1 compared with the presence of TPGS. According to the report of Nakagawa et al. [41], P2 belongs to pure HL dispersions and then P1 may be related to the appearance of BSFL oil. This implies that adding of TPGS would disturb the molecular packing of HL nano-emulsions. TPGS owning the PEG head group may provide a steric effect toward the neighbor molecule in the nano-emulsions. By compared with Fig. 4a and b, an increase of SOR induces a more obvious size of P2, and changes in the size of P1 at a low amount of TPGS. An increase of surfactant amount affects phase transition region which related to surfactant and BSFL oil interaction. This indicates that the surfactant may attribute to the original ordered crystalline structure of BSFL oil having a decrease upon the presence of TPGS [42].
From Fig. 4a, there is a slight change of phase transition shape in SOR 30%, and become more obvious at SOR 60% (Fig. 4b) from sharp multiple transition peak become one broad phase transition. This result suggests that higher TPGS concentration inhibits phase transition behavior change of BSFL oil and indicates an interaction between the surfactant and oil phase, which is contributed to the decreasing crystallinity of membrane with the presence of PEG head group [43]. On the other hand, the phase transition region of nano-emulsions with pure TPGS appears in the temperature range of 28.7–41.3 °C with a melting point at 37.3 °C (data are not shown). Nevertheless, the endothermic peak of TPGS was not observed in the DSC thermograms of NE, suggesting a complete molecular dispersion of TPGS in both oil and aqueous phase [44].
Table 2 presents the main phase transition temperature (ΔTm), enthalpy change (ΔH), and half-width transition temperature (ΔT1/2) for every recorded peak from DSC measurement. The result suggests that increasing TPGS concentration at SOR30% will cost decreasing ΔTm1 from initially 20.33 °C become 15.83 °C, where the changes become pronounce at SOR 60% and reach 8.06 °C. This result may attribute to the creation of the less ordered structure or
numerous lattice defects of the inner structure of the lipid matrix and/or the small size effect which could be explained by Gibbs-Thomson equations [45]. On the other hand, ΔTm2 at SOR 30% does not have any shifting behavior. However, increasing SOR to 60% possesses a decrease in the main phase transition temperature. This result suggests that in low TPGS concentration, the interaction between TPGS and BSFL oil is more dominant rather than the interaction with HL. Moreover, increasing SOR would make the surfactant interaction firmer. From ΔH1 data, there are no significant changes in SOR30%, but it rapid decreases while increasing TPGS concentration at SOR 60%. This finding suggests that higher TPGS concentration will give better thermal stability in NE dispersion, as they exhibit small changes in heat flow [46]. Furthermore, ΔH2 which belongs to the HL phase transition exhibit the same behavior even in high or low SOR which the presence of TPGS even in lowest concentration can reduce the phase transition region that makes the NE thermally stable.
In the case of ΔT1–1/2 and ΔT2–1/2 value, it clearly reveals that mixing TPGS and HL will decrease the phase transition temperature width which in the same evidence with sharpening the transition peak. This result is on contrary to [47], which explains that the bigger particle will crystallize at faster rates as compared to smaller ones. However, when mixing TPGS and HL will cost decreasing particle size and accelerate the phase transition rates.

sections.heading: Molecular Fluidity in Nano-emulsions
sections.text:
Lipid membrane in the nano-emulsions system is the outer layer, which the first part will contact with the surrounding environment while applied as a drug carrier. The fluidity of the nano-emulsions membrane is one of the essential aspects that affect drug delivery
P1 P2 Fig. 4 Endothermal DSC thermogram pattern of BSFL oil nano-emulsions varied with different surfactant ratios of HL/TPGS at (a) oil = 1%, SOR = 30% and (b) oil = 1%, SOR = 60%
performance. The high fluidity of a membrane may have good performance since its ability to squeeze and deform through the various physiological barrier [48]. The polarization of DPH inside the dispersion was found in the same value even in the different amounts of surfactant ratio and oil content (Fig. 5). It is possible that this result was affected by the forming of a gel phase under the observation temperature at 25 °C. Increasing SOR makes the polarization value of nano-emulsions decrease for all oil content 1% and 2%. This implies that the intranano-emulsions fluidity can be elevated by increasing the surfactant amount. But oil content seems not to influence significantly on the molecular fluidity in BSFL oil nano-emulsions.

sections.heading: Statistical Analysis and Optimization
sections.text:
The right composition of materials, such as a surfactant, oil content, and the ratio of surfactant is the key parameter to obtain an optimum formulation for preparing nano-emulsion and the statistical analysis was performed to find the relation of the independent variable to the response value. To get an understanding of mixing phenomena, a user-defined design with 5
different points for the surfactant ratio was carried out. Table 3 shows the ANOVA analysis which carried out using the two-factor interaction (2FI) model. The result suggests that the obtained model showed an actual correlation between independent response and variable, where the p value for average particle size (APS), polydispersity index (PdI), and zeta potential (ZP) was found to be p < 0.0001, p < 0.0039, and p < 0.0001, and the F value was found to be 30.75, 5.71, and 24.17, respectively. This result implies that all the model is significant. Furthermore, there was only a 0.01% chance that an F value this large could occur due to noise. Regression equations for each response variable, obtained from response surface methodology, are mentioned in Eqs. (2)–(4):
1=Average Particle Size ¼ 0:013þ 0:0062A–8:2E−04B−0:0068C −7:24E−04AB−0:0057 ACþ 1:8E−05BC
ð2Þ
1= Polydispersityð Þ ¼ 4:27–0:64A−0:082Bþ 0:37C−0:064AB−0:12 AC−0:081 BC ð3Þ
1= Zeta potentialð Þ ¼ −0:033−1:15E−03A−3:77E−03Bþ 0:014Cþ 1:46E−04AB þ 1:23E−03ACþ 4:58E−03BC ð4Þ
From Eq. (2), it was found that two factors (A and BC) affected the average particle size in a positive direction. When increasing surfactant in a specific range of oil content and surfactant ratio amount will decrease the particle size, then, the positive coefficient of C in Eq. (3) indicates that increasing the surfactant ratio will cost increasing of polydispersity. Furthermore, four factors in Eq. (4) (C, AB, AC, and BC) will decrease the zeta potential value, whereas the negative coefficient in all equations indicates an opposite effect on the independent variable.
The optimal condition for NE was determined using numerical optimization with targeting the minimum level of APS and ZP value and set in PdI lower than 0.3. The solution with maximum desirability value was selected as the optimized material composition. Thus, the predicted APS reaches at 32.4 nm and resulted in the composition of the independent variable as follows: SOR 59.87%, oil content 1%, and HL/TPGS ratio 0.114/0.886, respectively.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present study, oil was successfully obtained from fresh BSFL-based biorefinery and subjected to preparation of nano-emulsions. BSFL oil incorporated with mixing TPGS and hydrogenated lecithin can form nearly spherical nano-emulsions with long-lasting storage stability by a homogenization-ultrasonication method. The physicochemical properties of BSFL oil nano-emulsions, including morphology, size, size distribution, zeta potential, viscosity, endothermic phase behavior, and molecular fluidity of intra-particle, were analyzed and their results depended on their formulation constituent such SOR and SR. The presence of TPGS can reduce the sizes of nano-emulsions and improve the storage stability of HL nanoemulsions. Adding of TPGS would disturb the molecular packing of HL nano-emulsions, resulting in an increase of molecular fluidity in nano-emulsions. The information in this study will be useful for understanding the behavior of BSFL oil nano-emulsions and give a better design for preparing stable nano-emulsions dispersion for application in drugs, foods, and cosmetics.
Funding Information This study is financially supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology in Taiwan through grants 106-2221-E-224-045, 107-2221-E-224-016, and 107-2218-E-224-003.

metadata.abstractText: Insect-based biorefinery is seen as a potential alternative approach to manufacturing foods, feeds, and fuel because of the increasing demand for renewable and sustainable products. Insect oil and protein are the two major components that can be quantitatively obtained from insect farming. However, very few attempts have been conducted to utilize insect oil for the production of value-added products. In this study, the oil extracted from the black soldier fly (Hermetia illucens) larvae (BSFL) was used as a novel feedstock for preparing nano-emulsions. The nano-emulsions were prepared with BSFL oil, hydrogenated lecithin (HL), and d-α-tocopheryl polyethylene glycol 1000 succinate (TPGS) in water using pre-homogenization followed by ultrasonication. The morphology and the particle size of nano-emulsions were affected by ratios of HL to TPGS. Moreover, the nano-emulsions showed a nearly Newtonian liquid behavior and the presence of TPGS was able to improve the storage stability of HL nano-emulsions. The addition of TPGS could eliminate the phase transition region of HL nano-emulsions but did not provide a significant change for the molecular mobility in the HL nano-emulsions. In summary, the BSFL oil could be used as a renewable feedstock for formulating nano-emulsions from the aspect of high value-added applications and physicochemical characteristics of the nano-emulsions could be adjusted by the mixed surfactant ratio, surfactant to oil ratio, and oil content.
